title: 115_hr3980
content: The "Hate Crimes Commission Act of 2017" may be cited as the short title for this Act. The findings section highlights key points related to hate crimes. The Congress finds that hate crimes are criminal offenses motivated by bias against race, religion, disability, sexual orientation, ethnicity, gender, or gender identity. Forty-five states and the District of Columbia have laws against bias-motivated violence. The Federal Government has had hate crimes statutes since 1968, with the most recent law enacted in 2009. Underreporting impacts hate crimes statistics, hindering prevention efforts. Studies show a sharp increase in hate crimes over the past year. The increase in hate crimes has been significant, with over 900 new incidents reported since November 2016. The U.S. Commission on Civil Rights noted a 6.7-percent rise in reported hate crimes in 2016, one of the largest increases in over a decade. White supremacists and rightwing extremist groups were responsible for the most deaths in domestic terror incidents between 2000 and 2016, posing a continuing lethal threat. Additionally, there have been documented instances of anti-Semitism, attacks on LGBT centers, and White nationalist protests in Charlottesville, Virginia, highlighting the need for increased action against hate-based attacks. Establishment of Commission. The United States Commission on Hate Crimes is established with 12 members appointed by various leaders in Congress, including the majority and minority leaders of the Senate and House of Representatives. The United States Commission on Hate Crimes has 12 members appointed by leaders in Congress. Two members are jointly appointed by officials from the Republican Party. Not more than 6 members are from the law enforcement community or civil rights community, and no more than six members can be from the same political party. The Commission, appointed by leaders in Congress, is tasked with investigating the increase in hate crimes from 2007 to present, identifying contributing factors, suggesting law enforcement actions to reduce hate crimes, and addressing underreporting. A report must be submitted to Congress and the President within a year of the Act's enactment. The term "hate crime" in this Act refers to an offense under section 249 of title 18, United States Code.
